heading: case: netscape makes browsers?
subheading: aol's chief executive says he'll have nothing to bolster microsoft's defense when he's deposed as a hostile witness in the antitrust case.
author: reuters
text: america online chairman steve case says he will have nothing to contribute to the microsoft antitrust case when he answers questions friday about his company's acquisition of netscape. microsoft argues that its antitrust trial has been rendered irrelevant because america online acquired netscape communications last year.microsoft subpoenaed case to answer questions at a deposition set for friday in washington, before the trial resumes next month.the justice department and 19 states allege that microsoft abused its monopoly power to promote its internet explorer browser over netscape's rival browser.read ongoing us v. microsoft coverage - - - - - -case said that his company's purchase of netscape for us$10.1 billion -- which occurred after netscape had lowered the price of its browser to zero to match microsoft's price -- was not directly relevant to the case."nothing there has anything to do with operating systems, which, as best i can tell, is the focus of that trial," case told reporters after a forum. "we acquired netscape because we thought it has a great brand. we thought it had a great portal with netcenter. it had an important e-commerce business and a great team of people."he mentioned nothing about the web browser.copyright
